comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: I have a 1901 Map of the Abercorn Basin and it fits this exactly - the building on the left is the Deputy Harbour Master's Office, the one on the right the Pumping Station - with shipbuilding to the right.  Looking straight through the dock you see the Queen's Quay in the background, where as Shane points out would have been the coal depots, now the Odyssey.  I will scan and post the map tomorrow.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Some tantalising (but probably useless) dating clues in the Belfast News-letter.

The edition of 12th December 1893 describes the new electric lighting, "The illumination is provided by some 30 arc lights, each of 1,500 candle-power, placed at equidistant intervals from the Queen's Bridge to the Hamiton Graving Dock." There are lamp standards in the picture, but are they gas or electric lamps?

In September 1895 the jury at an inquest into the death of a schoolgirl who fell into the Hamilton Graving Dock recommended that chains be put up round the dock, but  all the Harbour Commissioners would agree to was "movable posts and chains at each of the five flights of steps at the Hamilton Graving Dock". 

It seems to have been a hazardous place - there are several accounts of workmen receiving fatal injuries there.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] If you look at this photo dated 1899 www.flickr.com/photos/niexecutive/5964358176/ you can see the lamps are different and must be the afor mentioned arc lights. which by default makes this photo pre 1893.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] The December 12th 1893 article also mentions gas lamps, so these must be the 'feeble' gas lamps.
Though the electric light was in operation, the gas lamps were in use as usual, probably by way of a contrast; and if so, no greater contrast could be witnessed than between the feeble, and, if we might use the description, circumscribed light of the lamps along the quay and the magnificent electrical illumination.
The 1899 photo also shows nicely the "movable posts and chains" at the top of the flight of steps put up in response to the coroner.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The ceremonial opening of the dock was performed by his Excellency the Lord Lieutenant on 2nd October 1867, and reported in the Belfast News-letter the following day. First he named the Abercorn Basin, then ...
THE "HAMILTON DOCK" The tug next steamed for the Queen's Quay, in order that his Excellency might proceed to the graving dock, which is situated to the left. On landing, his Excellency was again and again cheered. He was met by [there follows a list of dintinguished-sounding gentlemen]. His Excellency landed amid unbounded applause, and then made the circuit of the new graving dock, the various points of which were explained by Mr Lizars, the accomplished engineer of the Board. His Excellency examined some of the appliances with much minuteness. When the circuit of the dock, whose massive and symmetrical masonry was the subject of general admiration, had been made, his Excellency turned on the water and declared - "I name this the 'Hamilton Dock'" and declared it duly open. At this moment, at a preconcerted signal, a screen, which had obscured the words "The Hamilton Graving Dock" on the caisson - the large boat-shaped structure which gives entry to the dock - was dropped, exposing the name amid great applause. At the same time a screen which overhung the same words, painted on a board at the opposite side of the dock, fell. Here a device, consisting of the letter "A", and the red hand of Ulster, was also shown. The christening of this, as in the preceeding case, was accompanied by a Royal salute. Here a pretty smart shower fell, but fortunately it was of short continuance.
His Excellency then attended a banquet with the Harbour Commissioners and other distinguished guests, but the rain "prevented a portion of the firework display which was to have taken place". The dock was named after James Hamilton, chairman of the Harbour Commissioners at that time.

comment.author: 56514294@N03
comment._content: The SS Nomadic resides in this dock today.

comment.author: 41882809@N06
comment._content: I think this may be the RANGER, a clincher-built wooden paddle steamer (Official No 27,712) that came to grief on Briggs Reef in June 1895. If this is the RANGER, the picture obviously pre-dates that as it was a complete loss and was not salvaged. It was also the subject of a Board of Trade inquiry, details of which can be found online at www.plimsoll.org/resources/SCCLibraries/WreckReports/1671... I have had a very close look at the barely visible lettering on the side of the vessel and think it reads GER on the left and RA on the right, which cuts down the possible alternatives. Again, if this is the RANGER – and it is an if – I can claim some connection - it was owned by my great great grandfather Alexander Mitchell...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41882809@N06] Very interesting! I will try to have a look at the super dooper high res of this photo next week to see if I can make out whether it does have RA-GER on the sides...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41882809@N06] I've had a second look, but it's still difficult to say for certain! I'm concerned that I'm seeing RANGER, because that's what I want to see. Although as you say, starting with RA on the right, and apparently ending in GER on the left "cuts down the possible alternatives"...
